If a quadratic equation in the form  ax2  +  bx +  c  = 0, where a,  b, and c  are constants, has a negative a , what can be concluded about the number of zeros of the equation?
(A) One solution
(B) Two solutions
(C) One solution that is not real, and one imaginary solution
(D) None of the above
 (B)  Two solutions
Explanation: Since  a  is negative, the graph of this parabola will be a downward-opening parabola. Consider the  x -intercepts of the function and use the  x -intercept as test points. If the x-intercepts are both positive, both solutions are real. However, if one solution is negative and one is positive, then one of the solutions is imaginary and the other is real. Therefore,  a <0 implies that one solution is real and the other is imaginary.

Note that minor arc AD and minor arc BC together form a semicircle, which has a measure of 180°. So minor arc AD must be 180° – (minor arc BD – minor arc AC). In terms of the answer choices, minor arc AD is 180° – 30°, which is 150°. Note that if you forgot that minor arcs AC and BD together form a semicircle and had taken the answer choices at face value, you could have worked out that minor arc AD is equal to 180° – 160° – 150°. If you have trouble remembering that arcs and angles are related, think of the the sum of the measures of any two inscribed angles that cut off the same arc is 180°. The third inscribed angle cuts the same arc as both of the first two, and thus can also be labeled as the angle opposite the chord which shares the side opposite the arc being bisected.
